snippet: Despite criticism of the practice, federal appeals courts designate 88 percent of their decisions as “unpublished,” meaning they are good for one time only.
abstract: Adam Liptak Sidebar column points out that federal appeals courts issue 88 percent of their decisions as 'unpublished,' meaning they set no precedent; says Supreme Court has long been leery of unpublished decisions because they strategically avoid review, and can create sort of lawlessness by not establishing precedent for other courts to follow.
lead_paragraph: Despite criticism of the practice, federal appeals courts designate 88 percent of their decisions as “unpublished,” meaning they are good for one time only.

headline.main: Courts Write Decisions That Elude Long View
headline.print_headline: Courts Write Decisions That Elude Long View
